qas.question: What groups have become popular amonbgpublic schools?
What are two of the popular public school groups?
Who found the Classical Mandolin Society of America?
Who are modern mandolinists and composers?

answers.text: Samuel Firstman, Howard Fry, Rudy Cipolla

qas.question: What groups have become unpopular among public schools?
What are two of the unpopular public school groups?
Who found the non-Classical Mandolin Society of America?
Who aren't modern mandolinists and composers?

context: The mandolin orchestras never completely went away, however. In fact, along with all the other musical forms the mandolin is involved with, the mandolin ensemble (groups usually arranged like the string section of a modern symphony orchestra, with first mandolins, second mandolins, mandolas, mandocellos, mando-basses, and guitars, and sometimes supplemented by other instruments) continues to grow in popularity. Since the mid-nineties, several public-school <a0_0><b4_0>mandolin-based guitar programs<b4_0/><a0_0/> have blossomed around the country, including <a1_0><b5_0>Fretworks Mandolin and Guitar Orchestra<b5_0/><a1_0/>, the first of its kind. The national organization, Classical Mandolin Society of America, founded by <a2_0><b6_0>Norman Levine<b6_0/><a2_0/>, represents these groups. Prominent modern mandolinists and composers for mandolin in the classical music tradition include <a3_0><b7_0>Samuel Firstman<b7_0/>, Howard Fry, Rudy Cipolla<a3_0/>, Dave Apollon, Neil Gladd, Evan Marshall, Marilynn Mair and Mark Davis (the Mair-Davis Duo), Brian Israel, David Evans, Emanuil Shynkman, Radim Zenkl, David Del Tredici and Ernst Krenek.
